pr_title: Change JSON lib from Boon to Jackson

timeline.message: Abstract all JSON ser/deser and switch to Jackson
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:senx/warp10-platform into json_lib
Bump Jackson version to 2.10 and simplify API
Delegate the stricness to the json serialization lib
Use Jackson for serialization because it is faster this way.
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:senx/warp10-platform into json_lib

timeline.bodyText: How are .producer/.owner labels handled? The check for their exposure should probably be performed here too as this method might be called in the future from other places and responsability for exposing those labels might not be logical to implement in the caller.
timeline.author: hbs

replies.bodyText: Problem is that we don't  have access to the token here, so we can't know if internal labels should be exposed or not.
replies.author: ftence

replies.bodyText: Actually it should be fine since the labels will have been removed just after the FETCH if they needed to be.
replies.author: hbs

timeline.bodyText: This introduces a different handling of byte arrays whether it appears in a GTS/GTSEncoder or outside of one. Everywhere else byte arrays are serialized as b64, but here they will be serialized as an ISO-8859-1 string?
timeline.author: hbs

replies.bodyText:
You're right.
If you're fine with the b64 serialization of byte[] we could call getBinaryValue here and b64 encode if the returned value it byte[].
However, in the case of a GTS, we're stuck with an ISO-8859-1 string, correct me if I'm wrong.
replies.author: ftence

replies.bodyText: I am not too fond of emitting b64 content for byte arrays, why not simply output an ISO-8859-1 string?
replies.author: hbs

replies.bodyText:
This would unify the GTS, Encoder and byte[] representation for binary data which is nice.
There is a slight downside as it will produce a lot of special characters which will be escaped in JSON, making that not very compact. I think it's fine because JSON shouldn't be used for large transfer of binary data.
